titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
Rain great part of the Night, and continued this morning so that I lost my walk before breakfast— Visit from Mr Coffin of Boston— Drove along in the drudgery of the Russian and Turkish War, and am now abstracting from the accounts of the Battle of Koulevtcha or Pravody, which settled the result of the War, and it may be the future fate of the Ottoman Empire— From two to four O’Clock I took a ride on horseback, a mode of exercise which I believe indispensable to me for health; but troublesome and dangerous. I walked part of the way home, chilled through, but was obliged to spend the whole Evening in writing. My chief pleasure is in reading the Epistles to Atticus which are yet teazing by their obscurity— I have now finished the 13th. book; the last before the assassination of Caesar. In the 20th. Letter he says he had received consolatory Letters from Caesar, I suppose upon the death of his daughter Tullia. After this he appears to have been under no personal apprehension for his own safety while Caesar lived— But there are in many of the subsequent Letters half suppressed disclosures of the deep anguish in which he lived— He says in the 20th. Letter that things have been done which it was impossible for him not to disapprove. But he adds “I may fairly care nothing about them, which I do— But a truce with trifles.[”] In the 21st there is a critical analysis of the word “in hibere,” which he had used in one of his books addressed to Varro— He says he had mistaken its meaning and desires Atticus to ask Varro to change it— In the 23d. he complains that he cannot live with Brutus, and asseverates that his property gives him more pain than pleasure— Pain that he has no one to whom to leave it, which takes from him all enjoyment in its possession— In the 25th he intimates a fear that Varro who he
says is a tetchy man, may think the part assigned to him in the dialogue, not equal to that which Cicero had reserved to himself— He speaks several times of a Letter which he proposed writing to Caesar; in the 26th. he sends a copy of it to Atticus— By the 27th. it appears it had been submitted to some friends of Caesar, who object to parts of it; upon which Cicero concludes not to send it at-all. In the 28th. he returns to it again; and says how shameful would flattery in me, to whom even life itself is a reproach. In the 29th. he styles Cornificia, an old woman, of many nuptials. In the 31st he repels with indignation the pretence that Caesar had declared he would do nothing, but by Cicero’s advice— Let us said he throw away all this; and be half free; as I may be by keeping in my solitude, and being silent— In the 40th. he says—what? does Brutus announce that He (Caesar) is getting among the good men? brave news: but where are they? unless he has hung himself— In the 42d. he tells a dialogue with the Son of his brother Quintus who came to him professing penitence— Here says he I practiced some of your eloquence for I was silent— In the 52d. and last Letter, he gives an account of a visit which Caesar had paid him in which he had entertained him; at the Saturnalia, three months before the Ides of March— He says Caesar was very pleasant: Said nothing of politics—much of politics—very amiable—but not such a one, to whom he could very cheerfully say—pray come again.
2. V:15— Tuesday—

Resumed my walk round the centre of the Capitol Square, with a keen Northwest wind, and a flight of Snow— Riding on horseback as yet is too severe an exercise. A Mr Baussier came and enquired for a Memorial which he says he addressed and delivered to me, about December 1826—concerning a prosecution commenced by J. M’Pherson Consul of the United States at Carthagena—against him, as Master of a Merchant Vessel, for not delivering to him his Register. The object of the memorial was to obtain a dismission of the prosecution, there having been as he thought good reason, for his refusing to deliver to the Consul his papers; though he did not very clearly explain what it was— He said that he had neglected attending to the prosecution in Court, and now learned there was a judgment against him— I had some obscure recollection of such an application, and said I would have search made for the Memorial— My Son John did accordingly make search but found not the Memorial— In my narrative of the Russian and Turkish War, I have come to the Battle of Pravody or of Koulevtcha, on the 11th. of June last, which gave its final colour to the issue of the War, and nearly got through the event of that day— As this is the first attempt I have made at regular historical composition, I endeavor to reflect as I proceed upon the principles by which the work should be put together— My materials are most provokingly deficient— For the War with Persia, I had scarcely any thing but the English annual Register of 1827. For year 1828 I have little more than the French Annuaire; and for the year 1829. absolutely nothing but two broken files of the Journal of St. Petersburg both of which do not make a complete one; and neither of them bringing down the
official Reports of the Generals later than the 1st. of September— A copy of the Treaty of Peace signed at Adrianople, the 14th. of September cut out from a Newspaper is the only other document or voucher that I have— The narrative therefore is patch-works loosely put together, and with unseemly chasms, for the want of such simple documents as bulletins and official Reports— The plans of campaign I find it more easy to understand than I had expected— The narratives of Battles, I am obliged to take from Ex parte Reports, which are not entirely to be trusted— If the Story were told on both sides there might be not less difficulty to come at the truth—but in the great events there is no mistake— In abridging the official Reports of Battles, I endeavour to retain the critical incidents of the day; and the graphic descriptions—special traits of valour and occasional conceptions of genius which influence the fortune of the day— I group together the Transactions of each army, and the proceedings of the fleet as much as possible by themselves— The Affairs of Greece may have a separate chapter; and another is devoted to those of Turkey in 1828— There should be one for 1829. but I have no materials. I can give therefore no unity to the work. It is a collection of fragments— A Joseph’s Coat of many Colours— Nor can I so well put into it the heart, with the system of Arteries and veins through which might run one stream of pure political and religious morality little exposed to the surface, but felt in every pulsation— Thus should history be written—and lastly a rapid Style, enlivened by sagacity and inspirited with meditation should give to the whole the attraction of interest to grapple the attention of the reader— Multum abludit imago.
3. VI:30. Wednesday— Sun rose 6.

The Sun rose immediately after me, and I had barely time for my walk before breakfast, and to dress— Two hours of the day lost are irretrievable— The Epistles to Atticus suffer for it— William Emmons came to ask of me a subscription for a second Edition of his brother, Richard Emmons.—M D—his Epick Poem of forty Canto’s about 1000 lines in each, called the Fredoniad, or Independence Preserved—the largest Poem, William says, that ever was published in America— Some seven or eight years since, the Dr sent me one Canto, perhaps the 25th. in manuscript, asking my critical opinion, whether, it ought to be published or not— It was a delicate question— I thought the Poetry upon a level with that of Milman’s Fazio, or of much that I have written myself— I kept the Manuscript from mere bashfulness to answer the Poet’s searching enquiry, till he took an alarm for the fate of his beloved offspring, and in an agony of terror lest it should be lost, wrote to me requesting I would return it— I sent it back, declining as civilly as I could to give an opinion as to the expediency of publication— Three or four years afterwards, I escaped a worse fate by promising to take two copies of the book when published— It was published in 1827. and I took the two copies—four Volumes—forty Cantos— At least thirty thousand verses— The last couplet of which take for a sample of the whole.

lg.l: Never this Motto—never let it die—
Virtue, bless’d Freedom; Union, proud Liberty!

div.p:
It was dedicated to La Fayette—who wrote the Doctor a letter of thanks in which he styles the work an elegant poem, upon the strength of which, the Poet’s brother, Orator William is going about with a subscription for a second and much improved Edition. About ten days since he sent me this subscription paper, and this morning he called to solicit the
favour again of my name, which I declined giving.— I suppose the work not much inferior, but certainly not equal to Chapelain’s Pucelle, or Blackmore’s Prince Arthur Books not much better are sometimes now published in England. Bishop Brownell and Mr Richmond, who called with Mr Hawley to see me, are returning from a Winters visit to New-Orleans— Dr Huntt had some new gossipping tales of scandal which constitute the history of the present Administration— President Jackson has forced Mrs. Donnelson his wife’s niece who lives in the house with him to visit Mrs Eaton; and to invite her to the Christening of her child—to which Mr Van Buren stood Sponsor, and Miss Cora Livingston Godmother— And now the rumour is that Mrs Donnelson, is to go in the Spring to Tennessee— Mr Vaughan the British Minister gave a Ball, last Monday Night, which was opened by Mr Bankhead the Secretary of the British Legation, and Mrs Eaton— And Mr Van Buren has issued Cards also for a Ball, which is to be in honour of the same Lady— I confine myself to my Russian and Turkish War.
4— V:30. Thursday.— Sun rose 6.

Went out this Morning after Sun-rise— Mr Fendall brought me several Boston Newspapers, containing the controversy respecting the Article in the North-American Review, upon Pitkin’s History— I asked Fendall if he had commenced upon his History of the late Administration; he said he had not; but proposed to begin upon it very shortly— Mr Handy was here this morning, and mentioned that he had advertised Mr Baker’s house, but could get no purchaser for it— One person only had offered; and he wanted a credit of four or five years— Mr Handy asked me what I should be willing to give for the house— I told him not more than 1500 dollars— He said he would write to Mr Baker, to which I consented, and told him I was willing he should take six Months more to ascertain if he could get a higher price for the House— Mr Handy told me that copies of the papers relating to Timberlake’s Affairs had been sent to the Senate— That Timberlake as Purser to the Frigate Constitution was succeeded by a Man named Randolph— That Randolph received after Timberlake’s death a large sum of public money with which he paid for purchases—made by Timberlake and took the receipts as if paid by him— In consequence of which the honest Auditor and Comptroller now insist of crediting Timberlake with the payments; and charging Randolph with the money. Randolph complained of all this in vain; till being a Virginian, he went to the Senators of the State, and under apprehensions that they would take his part, Mr. Randolph is to be allowed to state his accounts and to have the benefit of his vouchers. The copies of the Papers are before the Senate, but the examination of Randolph’s Accounts is to be made not by Handy, whose business it is; but by some other Clerk, selected by Kendall and Hill— There is a possibility that by these samples of their address Kendall or Hill may fail to be confirmed in their Offices by the Senate— In anticipation of which there is a project for the appointment of a third deputy Post-master General, and sixteen Clerks. These appointments are made without the concurrence of the Senate, and Kendall is to be the third Deputy. I have been reading again the 14th. Book of the Epistles to Atticus— Written
all within three or four Months after the death of Caesar—while it was uncertain what turn events would take. He is still uncertain what to do— Frequently comforting himself, with the Ides of March, but finding nothing else to give him satisfaction— I consider the distresses and dangers of his situation from the Commencement of the Civil War by Caesar, until Cicero himself was murdered by Antony: and I say what are the trifling ills, that befall us now? The Letter from Antony to him about the restoration of the Son of Clodius, his Answer, and the enclosure of both to Atticus are all extraordinary— Ut audeant dicere— Tune contra Caesaris nutum?— I received yesterday and this morning the fourth Manuscript of 4 sheets from Blunt, and enclosed to him the sixth. Wrote also to Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston.
5. V. Friday.— Sun rose 6:

Returned from my walk to see the Sun rise. Mr Clements and Mr Bartlett are workmen upon the Canal, one from Maine, the other from New-Hampshire who came to see me, merely from curiosity— Clements said he was going to the State of Ohio, and Bartlett that he should return home. General Wool, was ordered here as a member of the Court-Martial, now sitting for the trial of Coll Roger Jones the Adjutant General; but he told me he had come too late— Mr White of Florida, called for his wife’s Album; but I had neglected to write in it as she had requested; and was obliged to ask him to call again— We received the American Quarterly Review, in which there is an Article upon Russia and Turkey, and one upon Mohammedan History, both full of information, upon the subject which now occupies me— The first is a historical review of the eight Wars between Russia and Turkey which preceded the last. There is in this review, reference made to at least thirty authors, French, English, German, Italian and Russian, to scarcely one of which I can have access— The writer appears to be familiar with them all— Karamsin’s History of Russia, and Von Hammer’s German History of the Ottoman Empire are works new to me— He says that Von Hammer is the most eminent Oriental Scholar that has ever appeared in Germany, and except Sylvestre de Sacy, has no rival in Europe— There is a short abstract of the causes and issue of every War between Russia and Turkey, from the first in 1569. to the eighth from 1807 to 1812—an animated account of the establishment of the House of Romanoff upon the throne of the Czars, in 1613. a rapid sketch of the character of Alexis, father of Peter the Great; and some dramatic touches of the History of Peter himself. A Satirical attack upon the Austrian Government for ingratitude to Prince Eugene, whom he calls the modest and valiant Eugene. This person is no favourite of mine— He was a Coriolanus— A Frenchman; born a Subject of Louis 14. bred to the Church, and after being in Ecclesiastical orders; deserting his Country, and going over to the Sovereign of Austria, because he could not obtain of the Government of Louis 14 a Commission as Commander of a Troop of horse. For this he invaded his Country and fought numbers of bloody battles against her— He went over to England too to raise a riot against the Tories, with the Duke of Malborough— There are other things too much against this same Prince in despite of his high reputation— The Article on Mahommed is not equal to the first, but has much information— The author Professes acquaintance with the Oriental Languages, and gives a severe criticism upon the Koran.
6. VI. Saturday.

Mr Sill introduced Mr Crawford; both Members of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania, and Colonel Dwight introduced Mr Foster, a member of the House from Georgia— I dined with my Son John at Mr B. O. Tayloe’s— The Company were, Mr and Mrs J. D. Dickinson, father and mother of Mrs Tayloe, who was also present— Mr Martin Van Buren Secretary of State, Baron Krudener and Mr Vaughan; Ministers from Russia and Great-Britain; Count de Menou, and Baron Stackelberg Chargés d’Affaires from France and Sweden. Judge Wayne, a member of the House from Georgia; Mr Rush: Mr Calvert of Bladensburg, Mr Fitzhugh of Fairfax County, Virginia, and Edward Tayloe— Mrs Dickinson had a sick head-ache, from an excessively crowded party last Evening at Mr Van Buren’s— I had some Conversation with Mr Vaughan, upon Captain Hall’s Travels in the United States; and told him I thought Nations might avail themselves profitably of the observations of Strangers, not friendly to them; by learning something of their faults— Mr Van Buren after dinner, asked me if I had read Mr Jefferson’s Memoirs and Correspondence recently published— I said I had not yet looked into the Book, though I had a copy of it. He said there was in one of the Volumes a considerable Correspondence with my father. I observed that there were some singular things in the book; and that they had given occasion to an interesting Scene in the Senate of the United States— He had said the book was very interesting— He said he thought Mr Clayton had been very wrong in introducing it into the Senate— I said I was not of that opinion— I thought the Senate was precisely the place, where it was proper that the exposure of the falsehood should be made— The book had already been introduced by Mr Hayne, to read a statement from it concerning me quite as false as that respecting Mr Bayard— But that which Mr Clayton read, was a gross imputation upon the integrity of Mr Bayard—a Man who was dead— The person stated by Mr Jefferson, as having told him the tale, and the person upon whom the corrupt attempt was said to have been made were now both present in the Senate— A more signal refutation of falsehood could not be given— The man named by Mr Jefferson as the propagator of the Report was there— The Man to whom Mr Bayard was charged with having made the dishonourable proposals was there— Mr Clayton calls upon each of them to answer for himself. Samuel Smith the man alledged to have been tampered with, denies it openly, explicitly, without qualification— Mr Livingston, the alledged Reporter, tasks his recollection and remembers nothing— The Slander is put down in the face of the Nation; and I rejoiced at it— He said he had not read the debate, and did not know that the book had already been introduced— That it was impossible to suppose Mr Jefferson had not received the information; he supposed therefore that Mr Livingston, had given it; but that he had been mistaken— I said to Mr Van Buren that he would do well to read the debate, which I thought the most important one that had taken place since the existence of the Government— The two doctrines were now before the Nation, and the existence of the Union, depended, as I fully believed upon that question. I said I well knew that the tale about Bayard and S. Smith, in Mr Jefferson’s book was
false; for Bayard had more than once, told me himself the whole Story of that transaction— It was directly the reverse of what it appears in the Book— Mrs Adams and Mary dined with Mr T. B. Johnson—
7. V. Sunday

Heard at St. John’s Church this Morning, Bishop Brownell from Matthew 6.10. “Thy kingdom come.” There was a collection taken up; in behalf of the Episcopal Society of foreign Missions, and the Sermon was an exhortation to beneficence in favour of that Society— It was a serious plain discourse, in a very temperate style of Eloquence, well written, with occasional elegance, read with propriety, but with little animation— There was more fire in Bishop Heber’s hymn than in any other part of the Service— The Bishop was more argumentative than rhetorical, and after stating some encouraging facts relating to the Society, devoted the remainder of his time to answering objections. As we returned from Church I had a visit from Mr Daniel Brent, and asked him, if he could furnish me with a copy of my Letter to Mr. Mallary; chairman of a Committee of the House of Representatives in 1821. being that, concerning which I have received a Letter from General P. B. Porter. Mr Brent said that General Porter had a copy of that Letter in the hand-writing of Mr. Maury, but that there was no copy of it in the Office— I mentioned to Mr Brent my wish to have copies made out for me, of all the papers written by me while I was in the Department of State; and proposed to employ Mr Brown for that purpose; and I desired him to ask Mr Van Buren’s permission for that purpose, which he promised to do— I asked him also for the loan of some more books; particularly Malte-Brun’s Geography, which he said he would send if at the Department. In the Evening I went with Mrs Adams and heard Mr Campbell from Philippians 1.27. “Only let your conversation be as it becometh the gospel of Christ.” There was a severe thunder shower during the time of the Service— I had much difficulty to get through my two pages of Turkish and Russian War.
8. IV:30. Monday.

I rose this morning by moon light, thinking it daylight— Walked out immediately after rising; and returned half an hour before Sunrise— Mr White of Florida called for his wifes Album in which I had written a few lines in a tone congenial with that of the title-page; which is satirical and jocular. Mr Southard called for the purpose of introducing three Citizens of New-Jersey, all now in attendance upon the Supreme Court of the United States. Mr Southard has been home since he visited me before; and returned— He now brought me back the manuscript which I had left with him at Philadelphia; and concerning which he said he would call and have a conversation with me— I have read a second time the 15th. Book of Cicero’s Epistles to Atticus— They were written between January and July of the year after the death of Caesar, while he was deliberating whether he should go to Athens or remain in Italy— In the first Letter he mentions the sudden Death of a Physician named Alexio, upon which he moralizes—concluding that for all these things there is this only consolation that we are born to such condition that we can refuse nothing which may happen to man— He says that Brutus has sent him, to correct the Speech which he had made at the Capitol—(at the Murder of Caesar) He pronounces the Speech well written, in very elegant language— He himself would in such case have spoken more ardently— But he could not correct the Speech of Brutus because it was suited to his character.— The person of the Speaker must be considered: and Brutus’s Oration was perfect, according to his theory
of the best mode of public speaking. Cicero asks Atticus what he thinks of it, fears that from his name of Atticus he will have a preference for the Attic Style; but hints that the thunderbolts of Demosthenes prove that the attic style can express great passion— He thinks Brutus’s speech too cold— In the 4th. Letter, he says that as things are going on he delights not in the Ides of March— That man (Caesar) would not have been so bad as these— Although he is dead, we are not free— Such a Master would have been good. I blush, believe me; but I had written and will not erase it— In the 11th. he writes of his interview with Brutus and Cassius at Antium: upon which he concludes to go to Greece, and says Dolabella has given him a free Legation— In the 12th. he mentions Octavius with doubts— In the 14th. he encloses copies of a Letter from him to Dolabella— In the 20th. he is greatly displeased at hearing Caesar called an illustrious Man— And says he will go away; not to fly; but in the hope of a better death— In the 27th he describes effectively his parting from Atticus and says he will send him his book upon glory— In the 29th. he complains of Quintus the son of his brother— And in many other passages he complains of Brutus and the imperfect Ides of March
9— V:30— Tuesday

In my morning walk I overtook Chief Justice Marshall, and walked with him from the hither end of the Pennsylvania Avenue, to his lodgings at Gadsby’s. He told me that the Supreme Court had before them questions upon the validity of large Land Grants in Missouri, and were much perplexed to ascertain the authenticity of the Titles; and he asked if through an official application to the Spanish Government authentic copies of their grants might not be obtained. I said it would I thought at least be expedient to make the application, though I had not much confidence in the result— There is a very formal Code in four folio Volumes of Spanish Laws of the Indies—in which the title concerning land-grants is very short— It allows only of grants of very small extent, and always upon rigorous conditions of Settlement— But the practice was very different from the Law— The kings themselves made enormous grants to favourites or purchasers; often without conditions of Settlement— They often gave power to the Governors to make grants; and the Governors often made grants without authority; and many of them appear to have been carried into effect— Of all such grants probably no record or trace could be found among the archives of Spain— But there would be another and a greater hazard in the event of such application— The chance that the Archive would follow from the grant, instead of the grant from the Archive— That is that the holders of enormous spurious grants would find the means of fabricating the record as well as the grant, by gilding the palm of the Archivist himself— Of Records of that kind no small number has been imported from the Havanna into Florida since the cession of that Province— I mentioned also another ground of distrust in Spain’s Records of Colonial Land titles— The Office of Archivist was purchasable, and he considered the Records in his Office, as his own property. This was the ground upon which the
keeper of that Office at St. Augustine had refused to deliver up the Records in his possession— There was also a great Mass of Florida Documents lost on the passage from Florida to the Havanna—having been taken by a Pirate— Mr Niles the Editor of the Register at Baltimore paid me a morning visit, and had some conversation with me upon the Tariff— I called this Evening at Mr Coxe’s house to see Mr Southard; but he was out— Met him as I was returning home— He said he would call upon me to-morrow— Supper.
10. VI. Wednesday.

A stream of Visitors all day long— Governor Cass of Michigan, mentioned the Winebago Indians who were here in December 1828. and who he said had gone home so well satisfied that last Summer they had made a Treaty ceding almost all their Lands; Mr Stewart and Coll. Lawrence were from Mackinaw and Green Bay— Mr Southard introduced Mr Vroom who is the Governor of New-Jersey, Mr White and the Speaker of the House of Representatives of the State— Vroom was one of the members of the Committee of Slander at the last Presidential Election— They failed in that State, at the Time, but got their Harvest after the principal election was lost— Garrett D. Wall was the first of this Committee of Slander, and when they got the majority in the Legislature they at first chose him; but he was obliged to decline; and this man being the second Slanderer they chose him, and now he visits me by way of liberality— Mr Poinsett and Mr. Mason late Minister and Secretary of Legation to Mexico and just now returned called upon me. Poinsett’s Mission, has neither been successful, nor very creditable to himself; and now he speaks with great contempt of the People of Mexico, whom he represents as excessively ignorant. I asked him how the last Revolution there was to be accounted for. He said it was quite unaccountable to him—that it was effected by 150 men; and that Guerrero had gone into retirement without any sort of necessity. Mrs James Baker and Miss Tayloe paid the Ladies a visit— Mr and Mrs Frye, and Mr T. B. Johnson were here in the Evening— I was doubly pressed with occupation in preparing manuscript for the press, and writing to Jos. Blunt at New-York—
11. IV. Thursday.

Mr Southard called this morning and took leave having received a summons to return to New-Jersey for an important Cause in which the State is concerned— The Cause here is between the States of New-Jersey and New-York, and is continued over to the next term. The State of New-York having entered no appearance; and the Court having taken Jurisdiction of the Cause. Mr Southard told me a hint had been given him this morning that he might perhaps be called as a witness in relation to J. H. Eaton’s engagements with the Navy Department in the case of the late Purser Timberlake— He said Eaton had been exceedingly urgent that Timberlake should be sent to Sea, and he Southard
considered Eaton as bound for Timberlake. Mr Hendricks and Mr Test came with three Citizens from the West, whom Hendricks introduced, but whose names I cannot recollect— W. S. Bourne came to ask of me a recommendation to Carey and Lee, Printers at Philadelphia, who are publishing the American Encyclopaedia; as a Translator. I told him that I did not know what his Talent as a Translator was; but that if Cary and Lee wanted that sort of assistance, a recommendation worth more than five hundred certificates would be for him to go and ask them to give him a page or two of French or German to translate, and for him to make the translation in their presence— This poor man is half insane, and spends his life in solicitations for appointments— A youth named George Harrison, a Son of Robert Monroe Harrison, now Consul of the U. States at St. Bartholomews came and told me his father had directed him to come to me and thank me for my kindness to him— This boy comes to apply for a Midshipman’s Warrant in the Navy. Two of his elder brothers have been in the Service; and both unfortunately drowned. I heartily wished him success. He said he feared he should not obtain his Warrant; the Secretary of the Navy having assured him that there was already a superfluity of midshipmen— I took an hours ride on horseback before dinner yesterday, and again this day.— Unwell this Evening.
12. IV:15— Friday.

Returned from my walk before Sunrise— Day without interruption of visitors. finished my Chapter on the Russian and Turkish War—Campaign of 1829. and commenced that upon Greece— Wrote to Joseph Blunt, and enclosed the seventh parcel of four sheets of Manuscript— The pressure of this occupation with all the others that I have is almost distracting— I begin with three chapters of the prophets; much of them so unintelligible that it were a desperate pursuit even to seek their meaning— Then eight or ten Epistles of Cicero; followed by two pages of Turkish War, sundry Articles of Reviews and Speeches in Congress published in the Newspapers— Not a moment of leisure is left me; and my Journal even loses some of its dulness— I have finished reading the 16th. and last Book of Cicero’s Epistles to Atticus— This book begins at the time when he left his home intending to proceed to Athens, there to remain till the commencement of the next year when other Consuls were to come into Office. It finishes when he had determined upon returning immediately to Rome. The last of all the Letters is indeed merely an enclosure of copies of three to Plancus, two to Capito, and one to Cupiennius recommending the case of the Buthrotians— The townsmen of Atticus in Epirus— Caesar had after his victory in the civil War, issued a decree for distributing Lands to his Soldiers in Epirus— The Lands of the inhabitants of Buthrotum had been taken to satisfy some of these grants— Cicero at the instance of Atticus had remonstrated in behalf of the Buthrotians— Caesar had issued an order that none of those Lands should be taken; and that if any of them should be taken, they should be restored to their owners, and the new claimant should be indemnified elsewhere— Then came Caesar’s Death; after which the new possessors insisted upon holding the Lands by his grant and the Buthrotians—upon holding their own by his decree. Plancus was appointed by the Consuls to investigate the case and decide according to
the Acts of Caesar. The Letters to Plancus are Letters of earnest solicitation in behalf of the Buthrotians— Those to Capito and Cupiennius, are to ask for their influence with Plancus. It appears that one of the last philosophical Treatises that Cicero ever wrote was upon Glory, “De Gloria.” And it is one of those that are lost— There is in this Book a Letter from Hirtius to Cicero: and one from Cicero to Dolabella— Dates of time and place, the res nummaria, many of the Roman Laws, and biographical accounts of persons, are all wanted for explanation— The Clavis of Ernesti is imperfect upon all those points; and if I should ever have the time I shall want to read these Letters again, with a translation, Commentary, and Middleton’s Life of Cicero—
13. V. Saturday.

Mr Hendricks, Senator from Indiana, introduced several of his friends— Mr Ilsley, was formerly the Collector of Portland, Maine; but at the expiration of his term about a year since, declined a reappointment—he paid me a visit this morning— Mr Newton, late and long a member of the House of Representatives from Norfolk Virginia came to take leave— George Loyall his competitor at the last election, contested his Seat, and the House have decided in his favour. He is a worthy and an able man, and lost his Election for his adherence to virtues, principles and to his friends— He says that his legal majority of Votes in the District was about 100— This is one of the afflictions which for the last two years have befallen me, and of which scarcely a single day passes without bringing its portion— I see nothing else in prospect—and the real woes that come are embittered with an undefined terror, of deeper calamities which are not foreseen; but will be felt sooner than seen— I dined this day with Mrs Adams at Mr Frye’s— I spoke to him after dinner of the money due to me by Thomas J. Hellen, for the expenses of his subsistence and education which I advanced for him, while he was at Cambridge— Mr Frye was his Guardian and my account solely for monies advanced has been due nearly two years— The judge of the Orphan’s Court made the most senseless and absurd objections against it in the first instance; which he afterwards gave up; and now Mr Frye says there are difficulties which he will explain to me in a few days— After finishing the Letters of Cicero to Atticus, I have read over again the Life of Atticus by Cornelius Nepos— It is nearly half a century since I read with my Latin teacher at Leyden. There is something worthy of remark in that affectionate intimacy between two such men as Cicero and Atticus; who as Nepos says was in equal esteem with Mark Antony and in still more intimate connection afterwards with Augustus Caesar— For Agrippa married the daughter of Atticus—and her daughter was married to the Emperor Tiberius—a very bad, but splendid marriage— Nepos says that he published the Life of Atticus while he was living; and only added the account of his Death after it happened. He deliberately starved himself to Death at the age of 77, having a fistula and a fever— Nepos says in the 16th. chapter, after remarking that Atticus when very young enjoyed the intimacy of Sylla, then old; and when himself old, that of Brutus in youth, as well as that of Hortensius, and of Cicero his own cotemporaries, adds that of Cicero’s friendship for him
the proof exists, not only in the books published by Cicero, in which he makes mention of him, but in sixteen volumes of Epistles to Atticus, written from the time of his consulate to the latest period: which whosoever reads will not much need a connected history of those times— For they discloses all the passions of the chiefs, the vices of the leaders, the changes in public Affairs so completely that nothing is left concealed—shewing that prudence is a sort of prophetic power: for Cicero not only tells what happened in his own life, but predicted the future; and prophetically sung what is now coming to pass— There is mention made in Epistle 5. of the 16th. Book to Atticus, of Cornelius Nepos.
14. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Campbell at the Presbyterian Church; in the Morning from Matthew 24.44. “Therefore be ye also ready: for in such an hour as ye think not, the Son of man cometh.” The duty of being always prepared for Death, and the general neglect of that duty, are subjects so constantly recurring to every Christian teacher that it would seem as if nothing but common place can be said about it— No preacher could discourse upon it so impressively to me, as my own conscience brings to it my daily meditations— All as yet to no purpose— Charles the fifth probably brought on his own death prematurely; by getting up a funeral service for himself while he lived— I would think of it every day and every hour of the day; might I be prepared for it when it shall come.— In the Evening Mrs Adams went with me to Church— Mr Campbell commenced his Series of discourses upon the Parables of Christ—by that of the Rich man and Lazarus. Luke 16.19–31. [“]There was a certain rich man, which was clothed in purple, and fine linen, and fared sumptuously every day.” &c to the end of the Chapter— This parable was spoken at a time when it is said the Pharisees who are covetous, derided him— It is a doctrine specially pointed against the pursuit of Riches— The rich man employed his wealth merely for dress and high feeding— No crime is charged upon him— Gorgeous Apparel and sumptuous fare, are the only faults imputed to him— Lazarus was not only a poor man, but a beggar, diseased and nearly famished— The parable seems to teach that enjoyment in this Life is itself criminal, and that suffering is itself a title to felicity here after— The concern of the rich man, for his brothers, while he is himself suffering the Torments of Hell, is a virtuous Sentiment, and pleads in his behalf. The main lesson of the parable is to restrain the passion for wealth— Mr Swann and Mr Peters called to visit me before dinner, and Chief Justice Marshall and Judge Story, after dinner— Peters told me he would send me a copy of an opinion delivered by the Chief Justice, upon a case in which the State of Missouri is a party. Peters said that the Review of Jefferson’s posthumous Works in the 12th. number of the American Quarterly Review, was written by a Young man named Gilpin; but that Hopkinson would write a Review of the same work, which he believed would be published in the Southern Review— Of which he said Mr Legaré was the Editor— I had some conversation with the Judges, upon the Indian question; and found that their opinions were in favour of a primitive Indian right of Soil.
15. V. Monday. Sun rose 6:7.

Returned from my morning’s walk in time to see the Sun-rise— R. Peters sent me the copy of the Opinion of the Supreme Court upon the Missouri case— It declares an Act of the Legislature of Missouri null and void; as being in violation of the Constitution of the United States. I received also a Letter from Blunt, with the sixth Quire of my Manuscript on the Russian and Turkish War— I have begun reading the Epistles of Cicero ad Diversos— The first Book consists of nine Letters, addressed to Publius Lentulus, Proconsul, and afterwards Imperator, and one to Lucius Valerius, a Lawyer whom he had recommended to Lentulus— This was one of Cicero’s most intimate friends— It was while he was Consul, and at his proposition that Cicero was recalled from exile, and had his property restored to him— The Letters are written in a style of affectionate friendship, and gratitude. Lentulus was Proconsul in Cilicia, and was anxious to obtain a Commission from the Senate, to restore by Military force Ptolemy, king of Egypt— Cicero made every exertion in his power to get the decree of the Senate authorising the Commission; but there was a Sibylline verse against armies in Egypt, and the intrigues of Pompey’s partizans, and of the enemies of Lentulus and of Cicero, defeated the project— The Letters of Cicero, give accounts from Time to Time of what was doing in the Senate. The ninth is a very long one, in answer to enquiries from Lentulus, how it happened that he Cicero had become reconciled to Caesar, Crassus, and even Vatinius— This was at the time, of the first Triumvirate, between Pompey, Caesar and Crassus— His principal Reasons were, the obligations he was under to Pompey, and the impossibility of accomplishing any thing in the Senate against the united influence of those three Men— He adverts to the general Rule that a public man should accommodate his conduct to time and circumstances—non idem semper dicere, sed idem semper spectare debemus.— In this same Letter he mentions the three Books that he had written de Oratore— These Letters are easier to understand than those to Atticus—having none of the Greek interlarding’s, and none of the designed obscurities— Lentulus was the immediate Predecessor of Appius Claudius, and he of Cicero as Proconsul in Cilicia— Mrs Adams and Mrs Frye spent the Evening at T. B. Johnson’s— I had no Visitors—
16. V:30. Tuesday.

Mr Peters sent for the opinion of the Supreme Court in the Missouri case, which I returned— I received a Letter from Judge Ambrose Spencer, now a member of the House of Representatives from the State of New-York enclosing a number of interrogatories in the case of General Peter B. Porter vs the United States in the District Court of the United States for the Northern District of New-York. Judge Spencer is appointed a Commissioner to take my answers to these Depositions, and requests me to name a time when I can receive him— The Count dal Verme paid me an Evening visit to take leave. He is going immediately to Virginia, and thence to New-Orleans— He told me he had heard some of the Debates in the Senate; which were interesting; but although a great Traveller, there is nothing in his Conversation which shews why he travels. The second Book of Cicero’s Epistles ad diversos contains seven Letters to Caius Curio, nine to Marcus Coelius Rufus, one to Caninius Sallustius; one to Quintus Thermus, and one to Caius Coelius Caldus.— They are all written after Cicero’s return from exile, and most of them while Cicero was pro consul in Cilicia. The Letters to Curio, are hortatory; as from an old to a young man; urging him to a career of Patriotism and glory. One of them; very short is a Letter of condolence upon the Death of Curio’s father. The next
is an apology for having advised Curio’s freedman Rupa, not to promise the exhibition of games, at the funeral— The reasons that he assigns for which are that Curio himself was absent. That all his friends were averse to the exhibition— That the People did not expect them; and that every body was weary of those exhibitions— The 6th. Letter is a most ardent solicitation to Curio, for his support in Milo’s canvas for the Consulate. The 7th. is from Cilicia, to Curio as a Tribune of the People—asking his influence to prevent the prorogation of Cicero’s Government— The Letters to Coelius are upon various subjects— Coelius had very earnestly urged him to take the side of Caesar, in the civil War, because it was the strongest. to which Cicero answers with great firmness and dignity— Curio and Coelius were both political trimmers—but it did not save them— Both perished in the civil Wars— Coelius Caldus, was the Quaestor to whom Cicero on leaving his Province left the command— He declined leaving it to his own brother as his Legate, to avoid misrepresentations— He chose to leave it to no Legate; but to the regular Public Officer, chosen by the People and assigned by lot.— I have also read a number of Articles in the late Reviews— One particularly by A. H. Everett, republished in a pamphlet, entitled British Opinions on the Protecting System— This is chiefly in reply to the stupendous political economist of the Edinburgh, and proves his utter ignorance of the Subject and the absurd inconsistency of his argument.
17. VI. Wednesday.

I was threatened with a sprinkling in my Morning walk; but afterwards came on a heavy rain— Mr Bayard of Princeton New-Jersey, paid me a morning visit— He said he had been with his wife passing the Winter with his daughter Mrs Washington in Virginia— Her husband was a member of the Virginia Convention; and she living alone in a large Plantation, wanted Society; and her father and mother have therefore been to pass the Winter with her— A visit of a few days here to Mrs S. H. Smith who is Mr Bayard’s Sister is an episode— Mr Bayard asked me, if I proposed to publish a Memoir of my father’s Life— I said it was my intention. He said he expected Mr William Jay would publish a Memoir of his father and spoke of a controversy between Mr William Jay, and Bishop Hobart about the Bible Society— Bishop Hobart preferring a Society for distributing the Episcopal Prayer Book— Mr Bayard thought Mr Jay, had much the advantage of the Bishop in that controversy. I began reading the third Book of Cicero’s Epistles ad Diversos— I have also been reading several Articles in late Reviews. I have now in hand the 99th. number of the Edinburgh—for October 1829. republished at Boston in February.— The first Article is a newly published life of John Locke with Extracts from his Correspondence, Journals and Common Place Books, by Lord King who is said to be the Representative of his Family. The Reviewer declines making an Article upon the Life and Writings of Locke, reserving that for another occasion; but now confines himself to the Book— There is an extract of a very good Letter to Lord Peterborough upon Education— There is some account of Locke’s intimate connection with the first Earl of Shaftesbury, and its origin, which was accidental— But Grahame’s History contains much more upon this subject— The extracts from his Journal are interesting; but his ideas upon classical Learning and upon History are marked with the peculiar character of his mind—Metaphysical— It is an old charge upon Locke, that he thought Blackmore
a great Poet— There is perhaps an exaggerated account of the Popish Plot, and an account of Lockes removal from the Studentship of Christ Church College at Oxford—and he afterwards went into exile— His intimacy with Sir Isaac Newton is a subject of much interest—though it appears to have been partially interrupted by suspicions on the part of Newton which bear an appearance of insanity— It is remarkable that this publication should have been so long delayed— Locke died in 1704. one hundred and twenty six years since— That inedited works of his should so long have existed without publication is surprizing.
18. V. Thursday.

There was lightening this morning while I was on my walk before day-light, with warm sultry weather; but it afterwards cleared away, and towards Night was called— Major Mercer called to introduce his friend from Annapolis— In my Chapter upon the Affairs of Greece, I have now come to the year 1829. and have no longer the benefit of the French Annuaire Historique— My broken files of the French Journal de Saint Petersbourg, give me a succession of facts with various degrees of authenticity and without chain of connection together— I felt something like Jean Jaques Rousseau, as he describes it in his Confessions, when he had advertised to give a public Concert, without knowing one note of Music from another. I finally got a file of the National Journal, for the last Spring, Summer and Autumn— I selected and read over the whole succession of Extracts from the English Newspapers relating to Greece and to the War between Russia and Turkey— Of the military Operations I found nothing but lame accounts of small affairs; but the Protocol of the Conference of 22. March 1829. and the Address of the Greek President Count Capo d’Istrias to the National Assembly at Argos the 23d. of July last are two important historical papers which I found— Five hours at least of eager application, gave me little more than these two Papers, and my own writing laboured, so that I could not accomplish my daily task of two pages before dinner— I finished it however this Evening, after returning from Mr T. B. Johnson’s where we dined— Mrs Adams, John and Mary, and Richard Peters, who was very social. Peters says he finds there is already in the Southern Review an Article upon Jefferson’s posthumous Works; so that Hopkinson’s can not go there— I told him that was not the place for it at any rate— The Southern Review, being already a sink of foul doctrines upon Constitutional Law— He said he thought Mr Bancroft of Northampton was probably the author of the Articles upon Turkish and Russian History in the 13th. Number of the American Quarterly Review. He spoke of a conversation he had a few days since with J. M. Berrien, now Attorney General, in which Berrien, admired the heroic Virtue of John Branch, Secretary of the Navy, for hazarding his place, rather than permit his wife and daughters associate with the wife of John H. Eaton, the Secretary of War— This is an indirect puff of self-admiration; for Berrien himself is in the same plight with Branch—though a widower, and having only daughters— Ingham too is a purist, and they form a party, against whom Eaton and wife, have the support of the Old horse-racer himself—of Van Buren Secretary of State, and of Barry, the Postmaster General— There has long been talk of Branch’s resigning or being dismissed. Mrs Wirt was here this Morning, and told Mrs Adams that Mr Branch had given notice to Mr Wirt, that he should quit the house, which he hires of him—in May.— I sent a note to Judge Spencer.
19. IV:30. Friday— Sun rose 6.

As I went out; a quarter before five, Venus was rising and after my return home I saw the Sun rise— William Lee paid me a morning visit, for conversation— The ransacking of newspapers continued all the rest of the day; as I draw towards the close of my Grecian Chapter— The third book of Cicero’s Epistles ad Diversos, consists of 13. Letters to Appius Claudius Pulcher, brother of the infamous Publius Clodius— Appius was the immediate predecessor of Cicero, as Proconsul in Cilicia. The Letters commence at the time when Cicero was going to the Province, and were all written during the year of his service there— They all indicate a very anxious desire of Cicero to be upon terms of friendship and of good Offices with Pulcher; but are full of complaints at his conduct in return— The Letters of Appius are not given; but from the references to them in the answers it is apparent that they also were querimonious— It appears that he arrogated not a little to himself, from his Patrician birth, in his intercourse with Cicero, who in one of the Letters chastises him for it. He tells him fairly that he thinks neither Appiety, nor Lentulity have any concern with the relations between them. Almost every one of Cicero’s Letters contains sharp rebuke of Claudius’s injurious conduct, and yet offers of friendship, and assurances of perfect good will— Immediately after Appius’s return to Rome, he was accused of Majesty and of Ambitus, by Dolabella who just at that time had married Cicero’s Daughter Tullia— Cicero takes great pains to convince him, that he had in no wise connived at these Accusations, and did not approve them. He says too that he had no hand in the marriage; but that it was made in his absence by his family without at-all consulting him— Appius was acquitted upon both the accusations, and was elected Censor, upon all which Cicero offers him his Congratulations. In the last Letter of the Book he intimates obscurely the hint of a hope that he might effect a reconciliation between Appius and Dolabella. The most remarkable feature of the Correspondence is the keenness of reproach, coupled with the earnest professions of friendship with which it abounds— Appius was father in Law to Brutus, and his daughter married one of the Sons of Pompey. He perished in the Civil Wars.
20. V. Saturday.— Sun rose 6:

Mr Vance, member of the house of Representatives, introduced this Mr Pugh, a native of Ireland, but who has been thirty years in this Country, and resides in the State of Ohio. He shewed me certificates from Mr Creighton, and from Judge Baldwin that they had known him these twenty years. Mr Ruggles, the Senator from Ohio, introduced also two persons of his acquaintance— Baron Krudener sat with me perhaps two hours— The sale of his furniture has been twice postponed: the second time from this day till further notice. He told me that more than a month since he had received information, that leave of absence had been granted him according to his application,
but that four Packets had since arrived, and yet he had not received his official permission— He should therefore go in a day or two to Philadelphia; and return here, to wait for his despatch— He said he should leave young Krehmer here as Charge d’Affaires; but that Mr Lomonossoff was coming out in that capacity— I had much conversation with the Baron, upon the Affairs of Russia, and of Turkey, and of Greece.— The allied Powers have not yet definitively decided the fate of Greece— He said that Russia was endeavouring to obtain for the Greeks the most favourable terms possible; and he thought they would be relieved from the payment of Tribute— But that they must receive Prince Leopold of Saxe-Coburg as their Sovereign— I asked what he would do with his Religion— He supposed he might be converted to the Greek Church— If not, that he would have trouble from that source— I asked him about the personal history of Generals Diebitch and Paskevitch— The first is a native of Silesia; born a Prussian Subject—entered the Russian Service at 18. in the time of the Emperor Paul— Was a Lieutenant in the guards—and being low in stature; and not handsome, Paul one day fixed his eye upon him at the Parade— The next Morning an order of the day appeared, announcing that the name of Lieutenant Diebitch was struck from the rolls of the army, “pour son indigne figure.” Diebitch went home to Silesia; but after the accession of Alexander was recalled or readmitted into the army. He then rose gradually until the campaign of 1813. when he was chief of the Staff of the Army which went to Paris, and discovered great ability in the combinations for providing the army with supplies: the plan of that campaign was entirely his— On the resignation of Wittgenstein, who was near 80 years old, and worn out, Diebitch took upon himself the responsibility of the Campaign, in which he so handsomely succeeded. He is a man of lofty ambition, and of good principles, and of dauntless personal courage— Paskevitch is a Russian— Also a man of keen ambition— He spoke also of Czenicheff, and Araktcheieff, favourites of Alexander; but bad men; particularly the latter, whose project of military Colonies he thought excessively mischievous and dangerous— Mr Frye was with me, when Baron Krudener came in—soon after went away, and came again in the Evening— He now told me what the difficulty was which he had mentioned to me last Saturday without explaining it— Thomas J. Hellen has lately come of age, and Mr Frye, is to settle with him his accounts as his Guardian— Thomas’s father died in 1816. requesting by his Will that I would act as Guardian to his children, and recommending them in the most earnest manner to my kindness. I could not act as their guardian, having been absent for years from the Country after their father’s death; but from the time of our return to this Country, Mr Hellen’s daughter who was then a child of 11 years old, was taken by my wife; who has always been to her as a mother; and she is now the wife of my Son John— The eldest Son Johnson Hellen, lived with us for years, at my expense, without cost to himself—left us, while we were at the President’s house; without notice to me; without assignment of a reason; and without the slightest acknowledgment of kindness received from me— A few weeks after we removed to Meridian Hill, he married my wife’s chambermaid named Jane Winnull, a bold and cunning minx, who had wheedled and dastardized him into a fit husband for herself.— Not daring to come to the house, he used to come to the entrance of the gate, where she would meet and walk abroad with him— And when she went from the house to be married to him, he had prevailed upon his brother Thomas, then at the adjoining Columbian College, to meet her at our gate, and escort her to the tavern in the City, where they were married.— My wife then let Thomas Hellen
know that she did not wish to see him any more— Johnson had long before ceased coming to the house— In all this I had taken no one step; and never had one word of conversation either with Johnson or with Thomas, or with the chambermaid, on the subject.— With the consent and approbation of T. Cook, the former Guardian of Thomas J. Hellen, I had sent him to the Academy at Exeter, New Hampshire to be fitted for the University at Cambridge— Then to Cambridge where he was admitted and was two years on the list of Students— I paid his bills at Exeter and afterwards at Cambridge in advance. While Mr Cook was living he repaid me from time to time— He died in 1826. The year that Thomas entered at Cambridge— Mr Frye then became his Guardian— My Son George, from my funds paid his Bills regularly for two years— Mr Frye made me two payments on account, without settlement— I had given Thomas the most anxious and earnest advice and exhortations to industry and frugality— At the end of two years I found he had been idle, dissolute and extravagant— He had been sent away from the College to a Clergyman in the Country for six Months— I advised Mr Frye to take him away from Cambridge, and place him where there might be a chance of saving him from ruin— It was necessary that he should complete his term at the Clergyman’s and obtain readmission at Cambridge; to obtain such discharge there as would enable him to enter another College—all this was done—he came from Cambridge in Novr 1828. my Son George settled and paid all his bills, and furnished him with money to come here. There was a balance of near one thousand dollars, due me for these payments of which last Spring I furnished the Account to Mr Frye, all supported by vouchers— Mr Frye wishing time to collect funds, I left the time of payment at his convenience— But now Thomas J. Hellen having become of age, and calling for Settlement with him—instigated by his brother Johnson asks Mr Frye, not to pay the balance to me, but to leave it to him for further investigation— Mr Frye says that as long ago as last December, he spoke to Johnson of this balance due to me, who said, “let him get it as he can”— because Thomas had been shamefully treated at my house. Which Mr Frye says he understood Johnson meant I should be cheated out of my money, because he thought I could not recover it at Law. Afterwards Mr Frye exhibited the account and vouchers to Thomas, who acknowledged them to be correct and just; but said he would pay me himself— Johnson too changed his tone, from let him get it as he can; to saying that Thomas would pay it himself— Mr Frye enquired if I was willing to take Thomas himself for my debtor— I told him no— If Thomas wanted of me any explanation of any one item in the account; I was ready and willing to give it to himself. But my demand was against Mr Frye as guardian; and if driven to my action to recover it, I supposed it would be against him— He said if there was an action, and it should be brought to trial, the reputation of the two young men, and especially of Johnson would be utterly ruined— I said that was their own concern; they had both forfeited all claim to regard or tenderness from me— Mr Frye said he wished to
think further of the matter; and perhaps to take legal advice what he should do. He believed he should pay me the money; make his charge; and take the consequences. He asked my advice, which I declined giving him, having a personal interest in the question. He said he would see me again next week. This Evening Judge Spencer and Mr Mallary of the House of Representatives called on me, and we had conversation concerning the Letter which I wrote to Mallary in February 1821. relating to the expenses of the Commissions under the Treaty of Ghent— Judge Spencer said he would come and take my answers to the Interrogatories in the case of General P. B. Porter vs the United States, on Monday morning at ten O’Clock— Mr Silsbee, with Mr Devereux of Salem, paid me an Evening visit. Mr Devereux enquired after Mr T. B. Johnson, and said he had been cotemporary with him at Harvard University— The day was thus absorbed.
21. IV:15. Sunday—

Heard Mr Campbell this morning from 1. Corinthians 7.31. “for the fashion of this world passeth away.” A charity Sermon in behalf of the Howard Society; for which a Collection was taken— Upon this text, declamation is easy, and Mr Campbell’s declamation was eloquent: it requires not a long life of observation to see by experience that the fashion of this World passeth away:— After the Service Mr Barber of Connecticut and Mr Hodges of Massachusetts members of the House of Representatives, with a Mr Lewis of Connecticut paid me a visit. In the Evening we heard at Mr Campbell’s Church a Mr Neal, from Mark 16.15 [“]And he said unto them, Go ye into all the world, and preach the gospel to every Creature 16. He that believeth and is baptized shall be saved; but he that believeth not shall be damned.” with which Mr Neal desired his hearers to compare Matthew 28.19.20. and Luke 24.47— This he said was the Commission of Christian Ministers— It was to go into all the world; and to preach the Gospel to every human being—and that this was not a temporary commission, granted only to the Apostles, but permanent for all ages, was expressly declared in Matthew 28.20. in which Christ says, “and lo, I am with you alway, even unto the end of the world.” It was also a Charity Sermon to be followed by a Collection, for the Presbyterian foreign missionaries—but it was not taken at the Church— Mr Neal said he should call upon individuals for contribution at their houses— Mrs Adams went with me to Church, morning and Evening. I finished this day, my Chapter upon Greece, for Blunt’s American Annual Register— He requested me to write one Chapter upon the Russian and Turkish War— I have written five. 1. On the War between Russia and Persia. 2. Russia and Turkey—Negotiations immediately before the War. 3. Campaign of 1828. 4. Campaign of 1829. 5. Greece— I have been obliged to write in great haste, and with a plentiful lack of materials.— The whole work makes 130 pages, and has kept me overburdened with occupation from New-year’s day to this time. I have sent the Manuscript, four sheets at a time, to Mr Blunt, to be sent back to me with a copy, for a final and general revisal of the whole— To the last chapter I have allowed two additional pages— But as he was urged by his printer for publication, before I could finish, I have consented to send him the manuscript for the Press, with a very slight revisal, and altogether in an unfinished state— I sent this Evening to Mr Blunt, the fifth portion of manuscript prepared for the press— It would have been no better however, if there had been allowed me a full year to revise and amend.
22. V:45. Monday.

Judge Spencer came at ten O’Clock this morning with a Mr Beekman of New-York, and took my answers to the Interrogatories in the case of Peter B. Porter vs the United States in the District Court for the Northern District of New-York— Judge Spencer administered the Oath and Mr Beekman took down my answers in writing. There was no person that appeared on the part of the United States— I enquired whether any Person had been notified— It appeared there had not been. The interrogatories were all specific except the last; which enquired if I knew any thing further on the subject which would be to the advantage of the Plaintiff; to which I answered that I had heard much, concerning the question, but could say nothing that I knew would be either to the advantage or disadvantage of the Plaintiff. Mr Beekman said he would write the answers over again before he would call upon me to subscribe them— While the Judge was taking my answers he was continually digressing upon Politics— He said he was opposed to the Bill now before the House of Representatives for increasing the number of the Judges of the Supreme Court of the United States; and I said I was against it too—considering upon whom the appointments would probably fall. He asked me also my opinions upon the Indian question— I told him that as to a primitive abstract right of Soil, owned by the Indians when the European Settlers first came here; I did not believe in any such right; and thought it probable his opinion differed in that respect from mine— As I knew those of Chief Justice Marshall and judge Story did— But as to the Treaties and the Acts of Congress I supposed our opinion would concur— He said he should be glad to have further conversation with me on the subject, and I told him I should be happy to see him any Evening when he should be at leisure. Dr Huntt was here and I consulted him upon my obstinate and troublesome Catarrh; for which he gave me some advice— Mr Niederstetter, Charge d’Affaires from Prussia visited me; recently from Philadelphia— He and his wife, a daughter of the Chevalier Huygens, are both much out of health, and are going to Europe next Summer. Mr Sparkes was here; lately arrived from Boston. He has yet published only three Volumes of the Diplomatic Correspondence in the Revolutionary War— There will be twelve Volumes in all and they will come only to the Peace of 1783—leaving then a Chasm till the adoption of the Constitution of the United States— But Mr Van Buren he says has no relish for these publications, and thinks none of them worth their cost. Mr Sparkes said he had settled with my Son Charles the Letters from my father’s Letter books, which should be selected to be included in his publication— He made some enquiries about Mr Dumas, concerning whom I gave him much information, and referred him to the first and second Volumes of Dennie’s Port-Folio for much of his Correspondence. I told him that Mr Dumas’s daughter after his death had given me three Folio Volumes, containing that Correspondence, which I lent to Dennie— He published
almost all the Letters, but never returned me the manuscript Books. Mr. Sparkes told me he had sold the North-American Review to Alexander H. Everett. Edward Everett was here this Evening, and told me that his brother had given 15000 dollars for three fourths of the Review; one fourth being the property of the publishers. He said his brother had written him to ask him, to write for the July Number of the Review, an Article on the debate still pending in the Senate upon Mr Foot’s Resolution concerning the Public Lands— He said he wished I would undertake it— I told him I thought I could not, and one principal difficulty with me was about whether the Article that I should write, would suit the interest of the work— He spoke also of the debate which will soon take place on the Indian question, and of the unconstitutional acts of the Legislatures of Georgia, Alabama, and Mississippi, assuming Jurisdiction over the Indians within their Limits. Upon which I said there was nothing left for the minority to do but to record the exposure of perfidy and tyranny of which the Indians are to be made the victims, and to leave the punishment of it to Heaven.
23. V. Tuesday—

Mr Frye called this morning and paid me the balance of the account of monies paid by me for Thomas J. Hellen while he was at Exeter and Cambridge— Among the severe trials, with which in the decline of Life I have been and am visited is the total failure of the Education of this young man, and the self-degradation of his brother Johnson. Invincible sheepishness is the vice of Johnson; and unrousable indolence that of Thomas— To have the charge of the education of such children, is a misfortune— There is no striking fire from lead— Johnson it seems has a Son; so that the breed is likely to be propagated. Mr Amory was in my time appointed Navy-Agent at Pensacola— He has been removed, and some hungry sycophant has been put in his place— He is thus far on his way to Boston, but thinks of passing some weeks in this place. Edward Cranch called with Mr Stearns and Mr Bulfinch, two young Unitarian preachers— Mr Bulfinch told me he was going to Augusta in Georgia— Mrs Johnston who was dressed in the extreme of the fashion said she proposed to pass the Summer at Philadelphia—but her husband would go to Louisiana to look to his Sugar Plantation and his Election— She thanked me for my verses in her Album— Mr Bailey was here in the Evening; much concerned about the Indians— He spoke also of the party manoeuvres of the present times. There is in the Senate a majority of two or three adherents to the present Administration, bound by the party Talisman to the support of all its measures— Now as servile as in my time they were factious— Jackson rides rough-shod over all the rights, and Powers of the Senate, relating to appointments— Many of his own party in the Senate are disgusted with him for it; but they dare not oppose him— Of all his nominations they have yet rejected only one—Henry Lee, of whose infamy the judicial record itself was brought before them— His appointment, was of Consul General at Algiers; and they at last rejected him unanimously. With that exception, the Roman Senate of Tiberius was the Prototype of the present Majority of the Senate of the United States— David Porter takes the place of Lee, as Consul at Algiers. As General
Saml. Smith’s vote is aussi une puissance, C Hughes has been appointed again as Charge d’Affaires in Sweden, in place of J. J. Appleton recalled— Daniel Brent told me that since the Commencement of this Administration, not a line has been received at the Department of State from Appleton; which is quite unaccountable; and gives some reason for his recall.
24. IV:30. Wednesday.

Mr M’Vickar is a Professor at the Columbia College in the City of New-York, and reminded me that he had seen me at the Cambridge Commencement the Summer before last— He is here on a visit and about returning to New-York— Mr Lockwood is of New Jersey; and has a contract with the Navy Department to furnish a supply of Live-Oak—but has got entangled with others so that he cannot fulfil his contract and now wants a modification of it which he cannot obtain. Though an entire Stranger to me, he came to ask my advice; told me his Story, and exhibited to me a number of papers relating to it— I advised him to endeavour to dispose of his Live-Oaks to Merchants in New-York or Philadelphia, who might want it for Ship-building— He thanked me for my advice, as a man, so much in need of it, as to snatch at any that is offered to him— I sent to Joseph Blunt, the sixth Quire of my Manuscript revised for the press, and received from him the copy of the 7th. with a half sheet of the first, printed, with many errors of the Press— The fourth Book of Cicero’s Epistles consists of fifteen Letters—five to Servius Sulpicius, and two from him—four to Marcus Marcellus and one from him— One to Nigidius Figulus and two to Cneius Plancius— All written while Caesar was in possession of absolute Power— Servius Sulpicius had consented to serve by the appointment of Caesar, as Prefect in Achaia, which Cicero much approves; one of the Letters from Servius, is the famous consolation to Cicero upon the death of his daughter. The other is the account of Marcus Marcellus’s being murdered at Athens by a man named Magius Chilo, who immediately afterwards slew himself. The two Letters from Servius Sulpicius are extremely well written; and so is that from Marcellus. The first four Letters to Sulpicius are deeply interesting—confidential effusions from friend to friend—disclosures of the temper and feelings of both, in the prostration of public Liberty, by the victories of Caesar in the civil Wars— The fourth Letter especially in which Cicero declares his approbation of the acceptance by Sulpicius of the Office of Prefect in Achaia, and relates the proceedings in the Senate for the recall of Marcellus from exile, and his own Speech of thanks to Caesar at that time is admirable— The Letters to Marcellus are equally instructive and affecting— Throughout the whole of this correspondence, the Sentiment of Cicero is uniform, that if the Pompeian party had been victorious, it would have ended in a tyranny more cruel and oppressive than that of Caesar. He considers the first triumvirate of Pompey, Crassus and Caesar the cause of all the subsequent errors and calamities; and although from a Sense of obligation to Pompey he followed his fortunes in the civil War, he always considered Pompeys desertion of him when persecuted by P. Clodius, as the first deadly wound to the Republic, and he disapproved of the whole course of Pompey, in the civil War.
25. V:15. Thursday.

Mr Inskip, and Mr Swannell were two Englishmen the former of whom has resided these ten years at Wilmington in Delaware— The latter has just arrived from England; a farmer from Bedfordshire. He comes with the design of purchasing a farm, and settling in this Country—somewhat alarmed at the prospect of troublous times in England— Especially at the Distress of which there is again great complaint— I advised him if he should come here to be careful and fix himself in a healthy spot— He spoke of Chester County, Pennsylvania, and of the Western part of the State of New-York; but without saying that he had been disappointed in the result of his enquiries here, he justified the conclusion that he was so. He complained of the continual increase of the Poor rates in England; but said he was a tenant both of the Marquis of Tavistock, and of Mr Whitbread, who were the greatest landholders in Bedfordshire— And that they both rented their Estates so favourably to their Tenants, that their farms were easily made profitable— He said that Lord Tavistock gave an annual premium of fifty guineas for the best cultivated farm in the County; and that last year he had received it— I took them, at least Inskip—to be Quakers— They said they came to see me, merely for curiosity.— Mr Neal and Mr Campbell came together— Mr Neal without directly soliciting a contribution, explained to me the object of the fund for which he preached last Sunday— It was for the education of indigent young men for the ministry— There were now he said about one hundred, who received aid to complete their education: but the demand was much greater than the supply; not more than 100 dollars a year was allowed to any one of their Students, and there were now in the Southern and Western States upwards of four hundred churches vacant for want of Ministers. I told Mr Campbell, that I had heard he was going to Albany: he said it was uncertain— That he should prefer remaining here—but he could not live in fire— I said I believed the subject which had been so troublesome to him would subside, and that he would be suffered hereafter to live in Peace. He said he believed so himself, in consequence of the investigation now going on in the Senate— I asked him, if the questions relating to Timberlake’s accounts and to Eaton’s connection with them, formed any part of the Subject in which he had been involved. He said only indirectly; as he had received information of the facts after his communications had become subjects of enquiry— I asked him who had been present at the Cabinet Meeting before which he had been summoned— He said all the members of the Administration, excepting Mr Eaton himself— And Major Lewis had been there in his behalf. He said that he had not been permitted there to justify himself— That the President had repeatedly with great violence refused to hear him— That he had asked only for the opportunity of producing the proofs of what he had asserted; and that Mr Ingham, Mr Branch and Mr Berrien were all satisfied of the perfect correctness of his Statements— The reliance upon the Senate however will be leaning upon a broken reed— Mr Webster came with Mr Hone, heretofore Mayor of New-York— Mr Hone mentioned he had called upon me at Quincy in September 1828. the day upon which I had been suddenly called here by the illness of Mrs Adams— He was then with H. G. Otis— Dr Todsen came and asked of me a declaration, indicating my Motives, for employing him in the Public Service, after having confirmed the Sentence of a Court-Martial dismissing him from the Army as a Surgeon. I promised to give him such a declaration if he would call again in a few days—
26. IV:45. Friday—

Rainy and Stormy Night and Morning. With an obstinate and perhaps incurable Catarrh upon the lungs I took this morning my usual walk round the Centre of the Capitol Square before Sun-rise, with a cold rain beating over my head, nearly all the time— It afterwards held up and towards Night cleared up with a Northwestern gale. I received from Joseph Blunt the original of my Manuscript p 97–112 upon the Russian and Turkish War, with two half-sheets of Letter Press— These I examined: wrote to him and enclosed his copy of the last part of my chapter on the campaign of 1829— My original Manuscript Chapter on Greece; which closes my work, and which he is to use without having a copy made, and sending him a list of the public documents which should be printed in the part of the Volume devoted to such papers. I have thus completed my part of this undertaking which has occupied nearly three Months of my time— It is my desire to employ the time yet indulged to me in this world well. In this case, I have written from two motives— First to perform a friendly Office to a young man, who has been a warm friend, and whom I have not been able in any other manner effectually to serve— Secondly to contribute informing correct opinions in this Country upon a subject of great political importance— Thirdly to operate if possible upon opinions in Europe, and especially upon the Emperor of Russia— The Success on each of these points is now under other controul— The work may excite little or no public attention—in which event all my purposes will fail— It will be seed sown on the wayside, scattered to the winds and of no use to any one: and as this will in all probability be its fortune, I have prepared my mind for that result, and waiting for suggestion from abroad of some other topic for experiment. I now read the fifth Book of Cicero’s Epistles ad Diversos—21. Letters to an from various persons— The first is from Metellus Celer Proconsul in Gaul, to him; an angry and threatening Letter, complaining that Cicero had attacked his brother Metellus Nepos in the Senate. Cicero’s answer is at once spirited and conciliatory. There is a subsequent friendly Letter from Metellus Nepos to Cicero, and one from Cicero to him— One from Cicero to Caius Antonius who had been his Colleague as Consul— Two to Publius Sextius—one to Cn Pompey; one to Licinius Crassus— Two from Publius Vatinius to Cicero; and one from Cicero to him— Three to Lucceius, and one from him— These are excellent; and the first to Lucceius, intreating him to write a panegyrical History of Cicero’s Consulate, he himself in a Letter to Atticus 4.6 calls valde bellam— One to Titius, consolotary for the loss of children; one to Fadius and three to Mescinius Rufus— Of most of these persons I can find no information excepting what appears in these Letters to and from them— A single Letter from Cicero, has been to some of them, the passport to the memory of ages.
