The Letter to Lucceius is elaborately written—and has been abundantly ridiculed for the broad and unqualified request that in the historical narrative, he would praise Cicero, even at the expence of truth— It was however to no purpose— It does not appear that Lucceius ever wrote the history, and the only specimen of his writing now extant, is one Letter to Cicero in this Book— That is written in a style, rather studied than familiar; and more historical than epistolary.
27. V. Saturday.— Sun rose 5:52.

Mr Marks, a Senator from Pennsylvania, came twice this day; in the morning to introduce a Mr Gray, and in the Evening Mr Greiff, both from the Western part of Pennsylvania: Marks is a very worthy man, who has kept his faith, unshaken, unseduced, unterrified, through all the popular frenzies of his State; always steering a steady course, and prepared for the event which will restore him to private life— Mr Bell the Senator from New Hampshire passed two hours with me— He was enquiring who had been the former Comptrollers of the Treasury— He entertains a feeble hope that some of the most profligate publishers of scurrilous newspapers now in nomination before the Senate for offices will be rejected: but he will be disappointed— He says he has a full conviction that from the 4th. of March 1789. to the 4th. of March 1829. in forty years the whole number of base and worthless characters that obtained access to the public offices, did not equal that which has got into them within the course of the last year— He is apprehensive that the enquiry into the transactions of Timberlake and Eaton will be suppressed. Upon a motion in the Committee this morning, to ask authority from the Senate to send for persons and papers, the votes were two and two—the fifth number Tazewell being absent—purposely as he supposes— The movements upon these nominations pending in the Senate, are intimately connected with a controversy between the Telegraph, Calhoun’s Newspaper here, and the New-York Courier Van Buren’s paper, upon the question whether Jackson is or is not a Candidate for re-election as President—the Courier insisting that he is; and the Telegraph declaring it premature to ask the question— Mr Van Buren has got the Start of Calhoun in the merit of convincing General Jackson that the Salvation of the Country depends upon his re-election. This establishes the ascendency of Van-Buren in the Cabinet, and reduces Calhoun to the alternative of joining in the shout of hurra for Jackson’s re-election; or of being counted in opposition. Tun contra Caesaris nutum? the first consequence is the suppression of all opposition to the nominations in the Senate—and the next will be a suppression of all enquiry concerning Eaton and Timberlake— Mr Willey of Connecticut and his Son were here— Mr T. B. Johnson and Mrs Frye were here. In the Evening Judge Spencer and Mr Beekman came, and took my signature to the copy of my answers to the interrogatories, of which Mr Beekman had made a fair copy. They have been this week, and taken Mr Monroe’s answers to the interrogatories addressed to him— They returned from London yesterday— Judge Spencer said he would call upon me again next week— Mrs Adams and Mary spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s—
28. V: Sunday

Heard this morning Mr Robinson, a Missionary of the Episcopal Church at St. John’s— His text was from 1. Corinthians 1.22. The Greeks seek after Wisdom— His discourse was a mere narrative of his own visit to Greece, as a Missionary from the board of Missions of the Episcopal Church in the United States upon which he embarked 31. Decr. 1828—and after visiting several of the Ionian Islands he passed over into the Morea, whence within a few weeks
he returned to this Country; and is going out again the next Autumn as a permanent Missionary from the same association— His account of the desolation of the Country by the recent War was affecting— It would seem as if within the last seven years, one half the population had perished— The condition of the surviving inhabitants is wretched beyond description; and yet their passion to obtain Education, and to seek after wisdom is almost incredible— Numerous anecdotes which he told tended all to illustrate this anxious desire for knowledge— They have now Lancaster Schools in almost every City, and they long for Bibles, Testaments and Religious Tracts. He says the Americans are great favourites all over Greece: but when he was there it was not so with the natives of Great-Britain— This remark was not acceptable to Mr Vaughan, and Mr and Mrs Bankhead, who were sitting in a pew almost under the preacher— Mr Robinson said it was not thought expedient to take up a collection, as there had been one so recently as this day fortnight but whosoever was disposed to contribute was requested to send his bounty to Mr Hawley— After Church I had an hour’s visit from Mr J. W. Taylor; who told me he had a long conversation with Judge M’lean; who has certainly made up his mind neither to seek nor to decline the Office of President of the United States— He assured Mr Taylor, with the most positive dogmatism, that Jackson will not be a candidate for re-election; And that if he should be he cannot be re-elected— That Mr Calhoun will be the nullification candidate; but that Mr M’Lean has no intention of serving as Vice President under Mr Calhoun. I told Taylor I had no confidence in any thing Mr M’lean says—and I gave him my reasons for this trust—which were a constant system of duplicity pursued by Mr M’lean throughout the last Administration, and particularly in his employment, and persevering patronage of Henry Lee— That Jackson will be a Candidate for re-election if when the time of election comes, he has a fair prospect of success I do not doubt— That his personal popularity founded solely upon the battle of New-Orleans, will carry him through the next election as it did through the last, is altogether probable— The Vices of his administration are not such as affect the popular feeling— He will lose none of his popularity unless he should do something to raise a blister upon public sentiment, and of that there is no present prospect— If he lives therefore; and nothing external should happen to rouse new parties, he may be re-elected not only once, but twice or thrice— And Mr M’lean will make no head against him— Taylor said he thought M’lean would be presented as the anti-masonic Candidate at the next Election—which may be—M’lean said that if Jackson should be a Candidate, any Man would be elected against him except Mr Clay— Mr and Mrs Frye, with their Son Thomas dined with us, and we heard in the Evening Mr Campbell from Matthew 25–21–[“]His lord said unto him, Well done, thou good and faithful Servant: thou hast been faithful over a few things, I will make thee ruler over many things; enter thou into the joy of thy lord.” The parable of the Talents. Nothing very impressive in the manner in which the subject was treated. I had expected some leisure; but the day was wholly absorbed by company. Extract from my Chapter 11. in the New-York American—
29. IV:15. Monday.

Mr Letcher, a member of the House of Representatives introduced to me a Mr Fellitt from Kentucky— Morning visits from Mr Eckford of New-York, and from Mr Pedersen Minister Resident from Denmark— Dr Todsen called for the certificate which I had promised him; but I had it not written, and asked him to call again to-morrow— Mr Bronson and Mr Shaw are two old Revolutionary Soldiers, now residing in the Western part of the State of New-York, one originally from Connecticut and the other from Massachusetts— They are now here in pursuit of Pensions, and told me they came to see me for what I had been, and that when they returned home they might tell their neighbours they had seen me— I rode on horseback, an hour before dinner, and was over wearied so as per force to cease from writing in the Evening. My catarrhal cough hangs upon me with ominous pertinacity, and the oppression upon the lungs, weighs heavily upon the Spirits— The 6th. book of Cicero’s Epistles is almost entirely composed of Letters to persons, who had been engaged in the civil War on the side of Pompey and were in banishment acting by their friends to obtain restitution, or permission to return to Rome. Among these are Torquatus, Caecina, Trebianus, Ampius, Ligarius, Lepta, Toranius and Domitius— There are many observations upon the origin of the War and the characters of Caesar and Pompey— Cicero himself was always kindly treated by Caesar—and had very great influence over his principal partizans— There were no proscriptions—no robberies of private property— In these Letters Cicero speaks with deference and respect, of Caesar— It was only to more intimate friends that he opened his bosom, in the bitterness of his Soul— Caecina had published a book against Caesar, and that was the greatest obstacle to his re-instatement. There is a very well written Letter from Caecina, urging Cicero to exert his influence for him, and pleading his own cause. In one of Cicero’s Letters to him he says Pompey was the greatest enemy to his own cause for which he had more passion that preparation— And herein says he, I admire the generosity, the Justice, the wisdom of Caesar. He never speaks of Pompey, but in the most respectful terms—though he has treated his person very harshly— These are deeds of War and victory—not Caesar’s— How handsomely has he treated me— He has made Cassius his Lieutenant— Brutus prefect of Gaul— Sulpicius of Greece—and restored Marcellus, though most incensed against him, in the most honourable manner. He concludes however some what ambiguously by saying that surely good men, good citizens, of unsullied reputation, cannot fail of being restored, while so many convicted of infamous crimes, had been permitted to return— Better satire than Logic.
30 IV:15 Tuesday

General Harrison called upon me this morning to take leave; intending to depart to-morrow to return home— He sent me a second copy of a pamphlet that he has published here respecting some unpleasant incidents which occurred shortly before he left the Republic of Colombia— That Government appears to be in a convulsive state between Military Despotism, and a Republican Constitution— Their Revolution was popular, and formed upon principle
adopted from the model of this Country. Their objects were Liberty, and Independence— But Independence could be secured only by War— War required Military Chieftains, and Victories, and then the most successful General became the Liberator— The Nation which houses its emancipation to a Liberator, must have him for their Governor; but there will be a great mass of opposition to his Government— Intrigues, Cabals, Conspiracies follow of course; and every one of these from which he escapes—or which he overcomes, hurries him on a step further to absolute Power— This is the State of the Republic of Colombia: liberated from Spanish tyranny, struggling for a Constitution; but ruled by a military Dictator, with an army at his heels— A Tyranny with the forms of freedom— Such a Government is jealous and suspicious: full of spies; eager to catch every incautious word of those whom it dreads; and turns every movement of a suspected person into Treason— Harrison arrived in that Country as Minister from the United States— He soon found himself an object of jealous observation. Inattentive to the admonitions of time and place he indulged himself in panegyrics upon the freedom of speech and action enjoyed in the United States. He was immediately marked as an enemy to the Government of Bolivar. From that moment every step he took was watched—every word he said was caught, scrutinized and perverted— He was made accountable for the loose talk of his Son, and of his Secretary of Legation, and soon signalized as a conspirator against the Liberator— He visited the British Consul and they were both charged with plotting projects of Assassination— He dined with a friend, and that friend was cast into a dungeon— His own life was not safe, and he was at last fortunate in getting safe out of the Country— After he had taken leave of the Government there, and was no longer Minister of the United States, he wrote a Letter to Bolivar, to dissuade him from making himself a king or dictator; which he has now published in his pamphlet, and which must have nettled the Liberator beyond measure— He says that Mr Vaughan, the British Minister here, has a copy of a Letter from Bolivar to Lord Aberdeen, complaining that the greatest obstacle to the settlement of Affairs in Colombia, is the accursed Government of the United States— But I doubt this— Dr Todsen called, but I was not ready for him and requested him to call again to morrow. Mr Robertson the Missionary to Greece, and Mr Gurley were here— I made, many enquiries respecting the condition of the People of Greece, which he answered— He said he was endeavouring to get a Meeting of persons who favoured the Cause of the Greeks and that Mr Webster had promised his Assistance. I told him that I attended no public meetings, and could not make an exception in this case, but that I wished well to the cause, and success to his
exertions— The immediate object of the contributions which he solicits is the Establishment of a printing Press, to publish books of education— Mrs Frye, Mrs W. S. Smith, and Mr T. B. Johnson were here— I rode Mr Carroll’s pony about an hour before dinner. My Catarrh is still distressing.
31. V. Wednesday.

Dr Todsen came again for the certificate which I had promised, and which I now gave him— A person brought me a copy of the Abridgement of Webster’s Dictionary for which I had subscribed— Thunder, Lightning and Rain, great part of the day— Received a Letter from my Son Charles which I answered— Labouring under oppression upon the lungs, what can I write that should be remembered— The seventh Book of Cicero’s familiar Epistles begins with Letters to Marcus Marius—four, written at distant periods of time— The first giving an account of games, exhibited by Pompey in his second Consulate— A fashion of treating the Populace, which Cicero disapproves— The third written after Caesar’s African War, gives a full exposition of Cicero’s course of conduct during the civil War, and particularly for his withdrawing from the Pompeian party after the battle of Pharsalia. The 5th. is a letter to Caesar while he was commanding in Gaul, recommending to him Caius Trebatius Testa, a lawyer—from 6 to 22 inclusive the Letters are to Trebatius himself written with great familiarity and full of jokes— I remember these Letters more than the others in general, from the impression of a former reading about 35 years since— Yet there is more of levity in them than in any of the others. Trebatius seems to have been a friend for whom Cicero had more kindness than Respect. He gives him advice in a tone of superiority and occasionally laughs at him freely. Yet at the most trying period of his life, at Rhegium when on his intended way to Athens after the Death of Caesar, he wrote his Topics; addressed to this same Trebatius, and sent them to him with the 19th. Letter of this Book— Ernesti’s Clavis says that Trebatius was a Tribune of the People in the year of the City 706. the year after the Battle of Pharsalia—and refers to Menage for some account of him— There are then 4 Letters to Fabius Gallus, and one to another Gallus—one of the former is about the purchase of some Statues, and another complaining that he had been made sick by a supper upon greens— Three Letters to Curius, and one from Curius to Cicero— The 30th. is a burst of indignant derision at Caesar’s Consul Caninius, appointed for a single day— The last two Letters of the Book are to Volumnius, one from Silicia—the other inviting him to come and take part with Cicero in exercises of declamation, to which he devotes his time, with Hirtius, Cassius and Dolabella—and which he says he will continue, if it shall please Caesar—

Day. Still as of the Month of January— But on the day of the Equinox I finished my Chapters upon the Russian and Turkish War, since which my Time has been wasted; that is I have done nothing that can be useful, and I am suffering distress of Mind. Longing for the capacity to give some value to the remnant of Life, and conscious that these aspirations must be vain— As the Spring advances the necessity of returning home presses upon me, and with it now some reluctance to go— A contemplation of the future darkening from day to day and the hope of Justice on Earth—extinct.
